title: Should we pursue enterprise customers or focus on SMB growth?
description: We're seeing strong interest from enterprise prospects but our current product is optimized for SMB. Enterprise deals require longer sales cycles, custom features, and dedicated support. However, enterprise contracts are typically 10-20x the value of SMB deals.

options.name: Pivot to Enterprise Focus
options.description: Dedicate engineering resources to enterprise features, hire enterprise sales team

options.name: Double Down on SMB
options.description: Improve self-serve onboarding, focus on product-led growth

options.name: Hybrid Approach
options.description: Maintain SMB focus while selectively pursuing enterprise opportunities

optionScores.reasoning: Enterprise deals offer 10-20x revenue per customer but require significant upfront investment. The $150k cost and 6-month timeline create cash flow pressure. ROI is strong long-term but risky given current runway.
Lower investment with faster payback. Product-led growth has proven unit economics at current scale. Maintains positive cash flow while building recurring revenue base.
Balanced approach preserves SMB revenue engine while testing enterprise market. Moderate investment with optionality to scale up or down based on results.

keyFactors: Enterprise LTV is 10-20x SMB but CAC is also 5-10x higher
Current runway of 18 months provides buffer for experimentation
SMB base provides stable MRR foundation
Enterprise sales cycles of 3-6 months delay revenue recognition

optionScores.reasoning: Enterprise analytics market is growing 25% YoY. Competitors are primarily focused on enterprise, leaving SMB underserved. First-mover advantage in AI-powered enterprise analytics is valuable.
SMB market is competitive but our product-market fit is strong. Risk of being squeezed by enterprise players moving downmarket and free tools moving up.
Allows market validation before full commitment. Can capture enterprise opportunities while maintaining SMB growth engine.

keyFactors: Enterprise segment growing faster than SMB in analytics
Competitors focused on enterprise creates SMB opportunity
AI differentiation resonates more with enterprise buyers
Market timing favors controlled expansion

optionScores.reasoning: High execution risk - requires new capabilities (enterprise sales, support, security). Resource concentration risk if enterprise deals don't close. Distraction risk to core SMB business.
Lower execution risk with proven playbook. Market risk from enterprise players moving downmarket. Ceiling risk on growth potential.
Balanced risk profile. Preserves optionality while limiting downside. Main risk is resource dilution across two segments.

keyFactors: Enterprise pivot requires new organizational capabilities
SMB-only strategy has ceiling on valuation multiples
Hybrid approach risks doing neither well
Current team has limited enterprise experience

optionScores.reasoning: Entering enterprise puts us in direct competition with well-funded incumbents. However, AI-first positioning creates differentiation. Risk of triggering competitive response.
Avoiding enterprise leaves segment to competitors who may then move downmarket. Defensive position in SMB is strong but limits strategic options.
Maintains strategic flexibility. Can observe competitor responses before committing. Selective enterprise deals build credibility without full pivot.

keyFactors: Competitor response likely if we enter enterprise aggressively
Enterprise success creates barriers through switching costs
SMB dominance can fund future enterprise expansion
Strategic signaling matters for funding and partnerships

optionScores.reasoning: Requires significant team expansion - enterprise sales, solutions engineering, dedicated support. Current team would be stretched thin during transition.
Leverages existing team strengths. Product-led growth scales efficiently. Engineering focus on core product improvements.
Requires careful resource allocation. Risk of context-switching overhead. Need clear boundaries between enterprise and SMB initiatives.

keyFactors: Current team of 5 optimized for SMB product development
Enterprise sales requires dedicated headcount
Engineering bandwidth is primary constraint
Founder time is critical bottleneck for enterprise deals

evaluation.synthesis: The council recommends the Hybrid Approach with moderate confidence. This option scored highest across Financial (8/10), Risk (8/10), and Game Theory (7/10) agents. The key insight is that your current position - strong SMB product-market fit, 18-month runway, and growing enterprise interest - favors strategic optionality over full commitment. The hybrid approach allows you to validate enterprise demand with 2-3 pilot customers while maintaining SMB growth momentum. Critical success factors: (1) dedicate no more than 30% of engineering time to enterprise features, (2) only pursue enterprise deals that align with existing product capabilities, (3) set clear milestone gates for evaluating enterprise expansion. The main risk is resource dilution, which can be mitigated through strict prioritization frameworks.
dissent: Resource Agent scored Hybrid at 6/10 vs SMB at 8/10, arguing that context-switching overhead between segments will reduce overall productivity
Risk Agent notes that hybrid approaches often result in doing neither segment well - recommend setting clear success metrics at 6-month mark

title: Should we build native mobile apps or improve our mobile web experience?
description: Customers are requesting native iOS and Android apps for on-the-go analytics access. Our current mobile web experience is functional but not optimized. Native apps would require significant investment but could improve engagement and retention.

options.name: Build Native Apps
options.description: Develop dedicated iOS and Android applications with offline support

options.name: Progressive Web App
options.description: Invest in PWA capabilities for mobile-first web experience
